docs.title: Bims
docs.text: The South African National Parks (SANParks) Biodiversity Information Management System (BIMS) was developed by tailoring the Freshwater Biodiversity Information System (FBIS) to SANParks’ needs.

docs.title: What are sites? – An explanation of the term “site”
docs.text: Sites are the geographical localities of occurrence records in latitude and longitude. Every occurrence record in the BIMS needs to be assigned to a coordinate, as that is the way the FBIS was created. Because of this, we have had to select artificial points to allocate occurrence data to when we only know that the taxon (genus, species, subspecies) occurs in a section or park. The artificial points have been called centroids but are not always located at the centre of a section or park.

docs.title: How to download a checklist
docs.text: Go to the Explore tab, which shows the map, and Search by clicking on the magnifying glass icon. Select (FILTER) your taxonomic group(s) of interest in the Biodiversity module and click APPLY. Select your section, National Park or Marine Protected Area of interest in the Spatial FILTER and select APPLY. You will need to click SPATIAL and then click South African National Park Areas and click on the spatial layer you are interested in and then select the specific area and scroll down to click APPLY. After this, click on Site Overview and then Dashboard on the far right of the page. Once in the Dashboard, scroll down and click Download checklist to the left of the graphs.

docs.title: Disclaimer about the interpretation of checklists
docs.text:
Checklists provide a list of accepted scientific names with locality data for a national park, marine protected area or section of one of these. Checklists from the SANParks BIMS should not be accepted at face value. The information that is used to produce the checklists has not been vetted and it is likely to have some errors in it. For example, users of iNaturalist and Observation.org may have selected an incorrect scientific name for an animal they have seen. Different sources, particularly citizen science platforms, can use scientific names of different taxonomic rank (species and subspecies) when referring to the same taxon, which in this case, is an animal with the same common name. This is not a problem when one scientific name is a synonym of the other, as the issue will be resolved through the use of the Accepted name. It is a problem when both the subspecies and species names are accepted but they are being used to refer to the same taxon (same common name).

To finalise a checklist, the incorrect or redundant name can be removed and the source for the additional, redundant name can be shifted to the “correct” name. If you are unsure which name to use, then consider the sources and number of sources and occurrence records for the two names. Another rule of thumb that can be used, is where a common name refers to a species, then use the scientific name for the species name, as opposed to where a common name, such as blesbok, refers to a subspecies, where the scientific name for the subspecies should be used. The online version of Wilson and Reeder’s Mammals of the World provides a useful resource for information on mammals.

Another issue arises where the wrong subspecies has been named for a park e.g. confusing blue and black wildebeest or Mountain zebra and Burchell’s zebra. There shouldn’t be two subspecies co-occurring in a park, and where there are two subspecies, the one with the most sources and observations is likely to be correct. In all cases, the historical distribution range of one mammal subspecies will include the park, and that is the species that should be on the list.

Below are some examples of redundant and incorrect names that appear on mammal checklists from the SANParks BIMS.

Incorrect Name Correct Name Common Name Notes Antidorcas marsupialis marsupialis Antidorcas marsupialis (Zimmermann, 1780) Springbok Subspecies name only used on citizen science platforms Caracal caracal caracal Caracal caracal (Schreber, 1776) Caracal Subspecies name only used on citizen science platforms Chlorocebus pygerythrus pygerythrus Chlorocebus pygerythrus (F.Cuvier, 1821) Vervet monkey Subspecies name only used on citizen science platforms Connochaetes taurinus (Burchell, 1823) Connochaetes gnou (Zimmermann, 1780) Black wildebeest One record of incorrect subspecies (Blue wildebeest) on citizen science platform. Otocyon megalotis megalotis Otocyon megalotis (Desmarest, 1822) Bat-eared fox One record of subspecies on citizen science platform Suricata suricatta suricatta Suricata suricatta (Schreber, 1776) Meerkat One record of subspecies on citizen science platform Tragelaphus strepsiceros strepsiceros Tragelaphus strepsiceros (Pallas, 1766) Greater kudu Many records of subspecies on citizen science platforms

docs.title: Key concepts
docs.text:
Site: A specific location along a river course where sampling or assessments take place.

FBIS Site-code: A unique name given to each site made up of:

  • Two characters representing the secondary catchment code e.g. G1
  • Four characters representing the river name e.g. JONK. This is currently derived from the 1:500 000 DWS rivers layer. If the river does not have a name on this layer, then the nearest river name is taken. For this reason it is important for a user to add the Original river name on the Site form if the river is unnamed (e.g. a small tributary).
  • A hyphen i.e. –
  • Five characters representing the nearest place name e.g. SIMONS. In many cases these five characters are replaced by a numeric value where a place name has not been identified. The Original Site Code and Original River Name from the original study are also provided.
  • The site code is generated automatically unless the user as a standard name.

River: This is currently derived from the 1:500 000 DWS rivers layer. If the river does not have a name on this layer, then the nearest river name is taken. For this reason it is important for a user to add the Original river name on the Site form if the river is unnamed (e.g. a small tributary). (See section 11.1 Create a site).

Occurrence record: One collection record for a taxon at a given site. This record may optionally include abundance data.

Search: The process whereby free-form text is entered into the search box and the matching records are shown on the map.

Filters: Often used in conjunction with search, filtering allows you to narrow down the result set based on predefined spatial, temporal and biological criteria, such as province, date, species, etc.

Biodiversity Module: A higher taxonomic grouping of taxa (and thus their related collection records). Modules can have their own dashboard implementations and data capture forms to capture information specific to the kind of taxa in the module grouping.

Abiotic Module: A module serving abiotic data including water temperature time series data and physico-chemical data.

docs.title: What is G3W?
docs.text:
G3W-SUITE is a comprehensive and modular WebGIS platform designed to simplify the management and publication of interactive geographic data. It provides a streamlined, fast, and autonomous solution for organizations and individuals who need to share their QGIS-based cartographic projects with others via the web.

Built using the Django web framework and developed in Python, G3W-SUITE seamlessly integrates with QGIS Server to bring desktop GIS capabilities into a web environment. It supports full interactivity, including data viewing, querying, editing, and analysis, all within a user-friendly interface accessible through any modern browser.

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

docs.title: Core Technologies
docs.text:
G3W-SUITE relies on proven, open-source software to deliver a reliable and scalable WebGIS solution. At the heart of the system is QGIS, which provides powerful tools for data management, editing, and map

Component Role in G3W-SUITE QGIS Desktop Manage cartographic data, perform edits, and design high-quality map projects. QGIS Server Publish QGIS projects as web services following OGC standards.

docs.title: G3W-SUITE Architecture
docs.text:
G3W-SUITE is built on a modular architecture consisting of three core components, each serving a distinct role in the platform’s functionality:

Module Description G3W-ADMIN - Central administrative interface for project and service management - Manages Access Control Lists (ACL) - Integrates an OGC proxy server - Exposes a RESTful API for external integrations G3W-CLIENT - Interactive web cartographic client - Enables users to view and interact with published OGC services Front-End Portal - Public-facing access point - Facilitates discovery of WebGIS services and thematic content

docs.title: Key Features & Capabilities
docs.text:
Using the G3W-SUITE web interface, users can:

  • Publish QGIS projects seamlessly to the WebGIS environment with structured organization.
  • Organize WebGIS services into hierarchical thematic and functional containers.
  • Manage users and groups with customizable roles tailored to functional needs.
  • Edit spatial data directly within the browser for quick updates.
  • Extent functionality by enabling additional modular features.
  • Define granular access permissions for services and modules on a per-user basis.

docs.title: Troubleshooting Common Issues
docs.text: Why can’t I see any layers in the WebGIS?      Your project might not be published or added to a Macro Group.        Fix: Make sure your QGIS project is published and assigned to an active Macro Group in the admin panel.    Why is the map blank or slow to load?      This could be due to missing base layers or unsupported CRS settings.        Fix: Ensure a valid base layer like OSM is set and your QGIS project is using the correct coordinate system.    My changes in QGIS are not reflected in G3W-SUITE      Updating the project file alone doesn't update the published version.        Fix: Re-publish the updated QGIS project and restart the G3W-SUITE services if needed.    The popup information doesn’t display correctly      Field aliases or HTML formatting issues may cause this.        Fix: Use the QGIS "Identify" tool to verify field names and ensure the HTML popup template is well-formed.    I get an error when trying to save edits in the WebGIS      Your user role may not have editing permissions, or the database connection is misconfigured.        Fix: Check that your user role allows editing, and verify the editing settings in the admin interface.    Why aren’t my symbology settings preserved?      G3W-SUITE supports most but not all QGIS symbology features.        Fix: Use simple categorized or rule-based styles, and avoid complex symbol layers.    My labels are missing or cut off      Label rendering may be affected by scale or layer settings.        Fix: Adjust label settings in QGIS to use scale-based visibility, and check layer order and priority.    Why can't I create a new Macro Group?      Only administrators can create Macro Groups.        Fix: Contact a G3W admin or ensure your user role has the correct permissions.    The base map doesn’t appear in the viewer      This may be due to missing URL or projection mismatch.        Fix: Make sure the base map URL is valid and matches the WebGIS projection (EPSG:4326 recommended).    I get a “project not found” error when trying to view a service      The QGIS project may not be published correctly or the path is wrong.        Fix: Check that the project is saved in the correct directory and published in the admin panel.

docs.title: Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)
docs.text: Can I use my own PostGIS database?      Yes. G3W-SUITE supports multiple database types including PostGIS. You can configure connections in the admin interface.    Does G3W-SUITE support editing from the browser?      Yes. Editing tools can be activated for specific layers and user roles. Make sure you configure edit permissions correctly.    Can I use a custom domain for my G3W instance?      Yes, with the appropriate server configuration and domain settings. Contact your system administrator or hosting provider.    What’s the best projection to use?      EPSG:4326 is recommended for compatibility with most web mapping tools and base maps.    Can I disable certain tools for some users?      Yes. Use the role-based configuration in the admin panel to control which widgets, tools, and services are available per user group.    Is it possible to embed the map in another website?      Yes. G3W-SUITE provides iframe embedding support for public WebGIS projects.    How do I localize the G3W interface?      G3W-SUITE supports multiple languages. You can set the default language per user or browser locale.    What file types can I use for vector layers?      QGIS supports a wide range of vector formats like Shapefile, GeoPackage, SpatiaLite, and PostGIS — all of which are compatible with G3W-SUITE.    Can I back up or export my WebGIS projects?      Not directly through the interface, but you can back up QGIS projects, database files, and G3W config manually from the server.    Is there an audit log or activity tracker?      G3W-SUITE includes basic logging features for some operations. For full audit tracking, consider using additional server tools.

docs.title: Why Choose this Product?
docs.text:
G3W-SUITE is an advanced WebGIS management system that brings the full capabilities of QGIS into a user-friendly, browser-based platform. Designed to simplify the publication, access, and editing of geospatial data, it provides a streamlined, modular solution that adapts to a wide range of user needs — from individual GIS analysts to large organizations. Here’s what sets it apart:

  • Seamless QGIS integration

    G3W-SUITE lets you publish your QGIS projects directly to the web as fully compliant OGC services, eliminating the need for any conversion or duplication of effort. What you build in QGIS is exactly what gets served.

  • Fully open-source stack

    Built entirely on open standards and technologies — QGIS, Django, Python, and OGC protocols — G3W-SUITE ensures transparency, extensibility, and freedom from licensing constraints or proprietary limitations.

  • Customisable theming and access control

    Organise your WebGIS services into thematic categories, configure visibility and functionality per user or group, and define precise permissions using role-based access control and ACL mechanisms.

  • Advanced editing and search tools

    Empower users to edit spatial features directly within the browser, configure various search modes tailored to your datasets, and expand capabilities by activating additional functional modules as needed.

G3W-CLIENT Interactive web client for browsing, visualizing, and interacting with published map services. Front-End Geographic Portal Optional public-facing portal for discovering services organized into thematic groups, ideal for branding and open data initiatives.

Sizing Your Installation:

Medium / Managed Use Suitable for NGOs, municipalities, or consultancies. Add the Front-End Portal for a more polished, branded interface for external users. Large / Enterprise Environments Designed for institutions needing high availability and performance. Deploy all three components behind a load balancer, with scalability and redundancy in mind.

Whether you're launching a simple internal tool or powering a complex, public-facing geospatial platform — G3W-SUITE offers a deployment path that fits. With its fully open-source foundation and modular design, you can start small and scale as your data, teams, and performance needs grow.

docs.title: Glossary of Terms
docs.text:
New to G3W-SUITE? This glossary defines the key concepts, tools, and components you'll encounter while managing or using the platform.

Term Description 🔐 Access Control List (ACL) A rule-based system that controls which users or groups can access or manage specific services, modules, or data in G3W-SUITE. 🗺️ Base Layer The default background map (e.g., OpenStreetMap) displayed when a WebGIS service is loaded. 📁 Group A sub-unit within a Macro Group that contains one or more published WebGIS services or QGIS projects. 🗃️ Macro Group A top-level organizational container used to group related WebGIS services by theme or function. 🔒 Feature Locking A mechanism that prevents editing conflicts by locking visible features during multi-user editing sessions. 🗂️ File Manager The section of the Admin Panel used to upload, organize, and manage supporting data files for services. 🌐 Front-End Portal The public-facing interface where users browse MacroGroups, Groups, and access available WebGIS services. ⚙️ G3W-ADMIN The administrative backend of G3W-SUITE, used for configuring projects, managing ACLs, OGC proxy, and accessing the REST API. 🖥️ G3W-CLIENT The front-end cartographic viewer where users interact with published WebGIS projects and tools. 📍 Geocoding Provider An external service integrated into G3W-SUITE to enable location searches by address or place name. 🛈 GetFeatureInfo A WMS request used to return attribute data for map features based on a clicked location. ☁️ Hosted Services Managed G3W-SUITE deployments provided through Kartoza’s GeoSpatialHosting platform. 📋 Layer TOC The layer tree or “Table of Contents” panel in the WebGIS client showing all active layers. 🔁 OGC Proxy A service that forwards OGC requests (e.g., WMS/WFS) to the underlying QGIS Server instance. 🌐 OGC Services Web services based on OGC standards, such as WMS (maps) and WFS (features), supported natively by G3W-SUITE. 🗺️ Overview Map A mini-map displayed in the corner of the WebGIS client, providing a broader spatial reference. 🔗 REST API Server The backend interface that allows programmatic access to G3W-ADMIN functionalities and service metadata. 🗃️ SpatiaLite A lightweight spatial database format extending SQLite to support geographic data in a single file. 🖼️ Thumbnail (Logo) A small preview image representing a WebGIS service in the client portal or admin dashboard. 🔗 URL Alias A custom, human-readable web path used to access a specific WebGIS service (e.g., /g3w). 🗺️ WebGIS Service A QGIS project published through G3W-SUITE and made available as an interactive web map via WMS/WFS. 🧩 Widgets Interactive tools that enhance the map client (e.g. Search and Plots widgets)

docs.title: Managing Users & Permissions
docs.text:
G3W-SUITE provides a hierarchical structure for organizing WebGIS services and managing user access with fine-grained control. This model supports flexible, role-based permissions aligned to both thematic and administrative needs.

WebGIS services are structured across two functional levels:

Level Description Macro Groups Top-level containers, managed by Editor1 users. Groups Sub-level containers within Macro Groups, managed by Editor2 users or Admins.

This two-tier system supports the delegation of responsibilities by assigning user roles based on administrative level and required permissions. The available user roles are:

Role Permissions Admin1 Full system access, including Django administration and core suite configuration. Admin2 Comprehensive control over the suite, excluding access to the Django admin panel. Editor1 Responsible for one or more MacroGroups. Can manage users and groups, publish services, define access policies, and enable modules within their domain Editor2 Manages one or more Cartographic Groups. Can publish and update services, configure access rules, and activate modules within their assigned groups. Viewer Can access authenticated WebGIS services and interact with available functional modules as permitted. Anonymous Has unrestricted access to public services or modules without needing to log in.

Admin users have full access to all File Manager contents, while Editor1 users have access restricted to their dedicated folder within project_data, matching their username. This ensures autonomous management of geographical data relevant to their Macro Group.

G3W-SUITE can be configured according to one of two organizational models:

  1. Single Level (No Macro Groups)

    Admins manage Cartographic Groups directly and assign Editor2 users where necessary. Editor2 users oversee services and access controls within their specific groups.

  2. Two Levels (With Macro Groups)

    Admins create MacroGroups, each managed independently by an Editor1 user. These users control all aspects of their MacroGroup, including content and user management.

docs.title: Adding Users
docs.text:
To create a new user, go to the Users tab and click the Add User button. This opens the System Users page, where you can define the following user details:

Category Details Personal Info First name, last name, email Login Credentials Username and password Backend Access Access to the administration interface (if applicable) Roles & Permissions Admin, Editor1, Editor2, Viewer Group Memberships Editor and Viewer groups Additional Profile Data Department, profile image

Once all required fields are filled in, click Save to add the user to the system.

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

docs.title: Viewing Users
docs.text:
To browse existing users, click the Users List button under the Users tab. The list displays key user information, including:

  • Username and assigned role(s)
  • Group memberships
  • Associated MacroGroups (for Editor1 users)
  • Account status (active/inactive)
  • Superuser or staff privileges
  • Account creation details

You can edit or delete users using the Action Icons located alongside each user entry.

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

docs.title: Creating User Groups
docs.text:
User groups streamline access management by organizing users with similar roles. You can create, edit, or remove groups, and assign users accordingly.

There are two types of user groups:

  • Editor Groups: Contain only Editor2 users.
  • Viewer Groups: Contain only Viewer users.

To create a group, click the Add group users button in the Users tab. You’ll be prompted to specify:

  • Group name
  • Group type
  • Users to include

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

Next up: Discover how to extend G3W functionality using integrated tools.

docs.title: Quickstart: 5-Minute Tutorial
docs.text: Ready to publish your first QGIS project with G3W‑SUITE? This short tutorial will guide you through the essential steps to get your WebGIS service online in minutes.

docs.title: Step 1: Update Project Title
docs.text:
This title becomes the WebGIS service ID. Without updating it, your service may be misidentified or conflict with others.

  1. In QGIS, open Project Properties.

  2. Under the General tab, enter a clear, unique name in the Project Title field.

  3. Click OK to save.

⚠️ Avoid using special characters or unnecessary spaces in the title.

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

docs.title: Step 2: Upload Database
docs.text:
G3W‑SUITE needs access to your data sources — uploading your project database ensures layers display correctly.

  1. In the top bar of the Administration Panel, click the Gear icon.

  2. Click Files to open the File Manager.

  3. From the left-hand panel, navigate to the project_data folder.

  4. Click New Folder and name it spatialite.

  5. Open the new folder, click Upload, and select your project database.

📝 Ensure the file path in your QGIS project matches the uploaded location.

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

docs.title: Step 3: Create Group
docs.text:
Groups act as containers for your published QGIS services. You’ll need to create one before uploading your project.

  1. From the Administration Panel, under Cartographic Groups, click Add Group.

  2. On the Group Creation page, complete the following fields:

    Field Description Name Internal identifier for the group. Must be unique. Title Display name shown in the WebGIS interface. Srid Spatial reference system of your project (e.g. EPSG:4326). Baselayer The background map layer to use as a base (e.g. OpenStreetMap).

  3. Once all details are complete, click Save to create the group.

💡 Not sure which CRS to use? In QGIS, go to Project → Properties → General to find the EPSG code.

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

docs.title: Step 4: Add QGIS Project
docs.text:
Once your group is ready, you can upload your QGIS project file to publish it as a new service within that group.

  1. From the Cartographic Groups page, click Add New Project.

  2. On the New QGIS Project page, click Choose File and upload your .qgz or .qgs file.

  3. Fill in the Public Title field.

  4. Click the Save button.

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

docs.title: Step 5: View Map
docs.text:
With your project published, you can now open and interact with your live WebGIS map directly from the interface.

From the Projects List page, click the Show Map button under the Actions column to launch and explore your live WebGIS.

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

Next up: Discover how to navigate and use the G3W Dashboard to enhance your user experience effortlessly.

docs.title: Data & Preparation
docs.text:
Before you start working with G3W-SUITE, it’s important to prepare both your QGIS project and its underlying data. This section walks you through the setup process — customizing the project, exploring the dataset, and getting everything ready for a smooth WebGIS deployment.

By the end of this tutorial, you will have practical experience in:

  1. Customizing the visual and functional components of a QGIS project
  2. Publishing the project as a WebGIS service using G3W-SUITE
  3. Creating custom search tools for fast, focused data queries
  4. Integrating interactive charts with the DataPlotly plugin
  5. Enabling online editing capabilities

docs.title: Data
docs.text:
We’ll be working with a modified dataset of central Berlin, extracted via the BBBike OSM Extract Service. The pre-configured QGIS project and database are bundled for convenience:

  • Tutorial_Data_G3WSUITE.zip

Once extracted, the folder contains 3 images and the following structure:

  • 📁 plots – Chart configurations for the DataPlotly plugin in .xml format
  • 📁 project_data – Includes the SpatiaLite database: g3w_tutorial.sqlite
  • 📁 projects – The QGIS project file: g3w_tutorial.qgs

Before publishing a project to G3W-SUITE, these two steps need to be completed:

  1. Update the QGIS Project Title

    This will be used as the WebGIS service ID. Leaving it unchanged may cause confusion or service conflicts.

  2. Upload the SpatiaLite Database to the File Manager

    G3W-SUITE needs access to your actual data source. If the database isn't uploaded, your layers may not load correctly.

💡 Want to use your own data? Use the BBBike Extract Service to download a custom dataset for your area.

docs.title: Data Preperation
docs.text:
To update your QGIS project title:

  1. Navigate to the Project Properties of your QGIS project.

  2. Under the General tab, and find the Project Title field.

  3. Enter a unique and descriptive title for your project.

  4. Click OK to apply the changes.

Make sure your title:

  • Clearly describes the content or purpose of the project
  • Avoids special characters or long whitespace
  • Is short, but specific enough to identify in G3W

Image credit: QGIS

Next up: Now that your project title is updated, we'll walk you through how to upload your SpatiaLite database to G3W-SUITE so your project layers display correctly.

docs.title: Editing Online
docs.text: G3W-SUITE allows for multi-user editing through a feature-locking system that prevents conflicts during simultaneous edits. When a user activates editing within the WebGIS interface, all features visible in their current map view are locked for that session. These features remain unavailable for editing by other users until the original editor exits edit mode.

docs.title: Step 1: Enable Editing
docs.text:
1. Go to the Project Layers List.

  2. In the row for the buildings layer, click the Editing Layer icon.

  3. In the pop-up dialog, tick the checkbox next to Active.

  4. Complete the following fields:

    Field Field Input Description Scale 2500 The map scale used to define the initial zoom level. User Viewer Groups Viewer Group The group assigned viewer-level access to the project.

  5. Click OK to apply the changes.

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

docs.title: Step 2: Edit WebGIS
docs.text:
1. On the Project Layers List page, click Show Map.

  2. In the left-hand panel, expand Editing Layers.

  3. Click the Edit Layer icon next to the buildings layer.

  4. Zoom in to an open area on the map where no buildings currently exist.

  5. In the left-hand panel, click Add Feature and draw a new shape directly on the basemap.

  6. In the Editing Attributes panel, fill in the relevant attribute fields.

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

docs.title: Step 3: Save Edits
docs.text:
1. At the bottom of the attribute form, click Insert/Edit to commit your input.

  2. In the left-hand panel, click the Save or Checkmark icon to finalize your changes.

Your new buildings feature is now saved and visible in the WebGIS environment.

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

docs.title: Uploading to the File Manager
docs.text: To ensure your project layers display correctly in G3W-SUITE, you need to upload your database. G3W-SUITE must have access to the actual data source used in your QGIS project — otherwise, your layers may fail to load.

docs.title: Step 1: Access the File Manager
docs.text:
1. Go to the G3W-SUITE Administration Panel.

  2. Click the Gear icon in the top navigation bar.

  3. Under File Manager, select Files.

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

docs.title: Step 2: Create a Spatialite Folder
docs.text:
1. In the left-hand menu of the File Manager, navigate to the project_data folder.

  2. Click New Folder in the top navigation bar.

  3. Name the folder spatialite and click Create Folder.

📝 Ensure the file path exactly matches what is defined in your QGIS project.

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

docs.title: Step 3: Upload the Database
docs.text:
1. Open the newly created spatialite folder.

  2. Click Upload in the top navigation bar.

  3. Select and upload the file named g3w_tutorial.sqlite.

Once uploaded, your SpatiaLite database is ready to support your WebGIS services within G3W-SUITE.

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

Next up: Learn how to group and structure your map layers using Cartographic Macro Groups for a clearer WebGIS experience.

docs.title: Creating Groups
docs.text: To further organize your project's individual map layers within a Cartographic Macro Group, you’ll use Cartographic Groups. These are subcategories inside a Macro Group that hold individual WebGIS services (i.e., your published QGIS projects). This is the final setup step before publishing your project live on the WebGIS platform.

docs.title: Step 1: Access Creation Page
docs.text:
1. Navigate to the Administration Panel left-hand menu.

  2. Click Cartographic Groups.

  3. Select Add Group from the dropdown.

  4. The Group Creation page will open.

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

docs.title: Step 2: Create Group
docs.text:
1. On the Group Creation page, enter the following:

    Field Input Description Name Berlin City Center Internal identifier used by administrators Title Berlin City Center Display name shown to WebGIS users Macro Groups G3W Tutorial Select the relevant Macro Group container GEO Data EPSG:4326 Coordinate Reference System (CRS) of the project Baselayers OSM (OpenStreetMap) Default background map for the WebGIS interface

  2. Click the + icon in the ACL Users section to configure permissions.

  3. Assign Editor, Viewer, and Group roles as needed.

  4. Under Logo Image, click Choose File.

  5. Upload the image_group.png file from the Tutorial_Data_G3WSUITE folder.

  6. Click Save to create the group.

💡 Need to check your project's CRS? In QGIS, go to Project → Properties → General and confirm the EPSG code.

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

docs.title: Step 3: View Groups List
docs.text:
1. In the left-hand menu, click Cartographic Groups.

  2. Select Groups List.

  3. From the Cartographic Groups List, you can:

    • Add projects to the group
    • View existing projects
    • Display group information
    • Edit group settings
    • Delete the group

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

Next up: Discover how to publish your customized QGIS project as a live WebGIS service.

docs.title: Creating Macro Groups
docs.text:
Once you’ve updated the project title (to generate a unique WebGIS service ID) and uploaded your SpatiaLite database to the correct folder in the File Manager, you're almost ready to publish your QGIS project as a WebGIS service using G3W-SUITE.

The next step is to create a Cartographic Macro Groups that act as top-level thematic container and helps you organize related WebGIS services under a common category.

docs.title: Step 1: Access Creation Page
docs.text:
1. Navigate to the G3W-SUITE Administration Panel.

  2. In the left-hand menu, click Macro Cartographic Groups.

  3. From the dropdown, select Add MACRO Group.

  4. The MACRO Group Creation page will open.

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

docs.title: Step 2: Create Macro Group
docs.text:
1. On the MACRO Group Creation page, complete the following fields:

    Field Input Description Identification name G3W Tutorial Used internally to uniquely identify the Macro Group Title G3W Tutorial Displayed to users in the WebGIS interface

  2. Under Logo Image, click Choose File.

  3. Upload the image_macro_group.png file from the Tutorial_Data_G3WSUITE folder.

  4. Click Save to create the Macro Group.

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

docs.title: Step 3: View Macro Groups
docs.text:
1. From the Administration Panel, click Macro Cartographic Groups again.

  2. Select MACRO Groups List from the dropdown.

  3. You can View, Edit, or Delete existing Macro Groups using the available Action icons.

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

Next up: Learn how to create Cartographic Groups to better organize and manage your project’s individual map layers.

docs.title: Publishing a QGIS Project
docs.text:
After creating both a Macro Cartographic Group and a Cartographic Group to organize your content, you're ready to publish your QGIS project as a WebGIS Service using G3W-SUITE.

As part of the publishing process, you can configure several important settings that define how your WebGIS functions at runtime:

Option Description Tab's TOC active as default Automatically opens the Table of Contents (Layers, Base Layers, etc.) on load. Tab's TOC layer initial status Set whether TOC layers start collapsed or expanded. Map themes list initial status Choose whether the map theme list is initially collapsed or expanded. Legend position rendering Display the legend in a separate tab or directly within the TOC panel. WMS GetMap image format Set the preferred image format for WMS GetMap requests. Max feature to get for query Define the maximum number of features returned in a single query. Query control mode Specify whether users can select a single or multiple features during queries. Query by bbox control mode Choose single or multiple selection for bounding box-based queries. Query by polygon control mode Choose single or multiple selection for polygon-based queries. Geocoding providers Enable specific services for address-based searches.

docs.title: Step 1: Open Project Publishing Page
docs.text:
1. Go to the Cartographic Groups page.

  2. Under the Berlin City Center group, click Add New Project.

  3. This opens the New QGIS Project page.

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

docs.title: Step 2: Publish QGIS Project
docs.text:
1. On the New QGIS Project page, fill in the following details:

    Field Field Input Description QGIS Project g3w_tutorial.qgz The .qgz or .qgs file for your QGIS project. Public Title Berlin - BBBike Service The name that will appear in the WebGIS interface. Thumbnail image_project.png A representative image shown in the project list. Base Layer OSM (OpenStreetMap) The default base map when the WebGIS loads.

  2. In the ACL Users section, click + to assign roles as needed.

  3. Under Options and Actions, leave the default settings unchanged.

  4. Click Save to publish the project.

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

docs.title: Step 3: Launch WebGIS Service
docs.text:
1. Return to the Cartographic Groups page.

  2. Under Berlin City Center group, click Group Projects.

  3. This opens the Project List page.

  4. Click Show Map under the Actions column to open the live WebGIS.

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

docs.title: Step 4: Enable the Overview Map
docs.text:
1. On the Project List page, find the Berlin - BBBike Service entry.

  2. Check the box under the Panoramic column.

  3. An Overview Map will appear in the WebGIS interface, providing spatial context as you navigate.

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

Next up: Learn how to improve your WebGIS by enabling helpful widgets and interactive tools that enhance user experience.

docs.title: Widgets & Additional Functions
docs.text:
Once your project is published, you can further enrich your WebGIS service by enabling a variety of widgets and additional interactive features.

From the Project List page, each project includes a set of Tools that let you manage and configure advanced functionalities:

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

Click the Layers icon to access the QGIS Project Layers page. Here, the Actions column allows you to set up a range of layer-specific functions:

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

docs.title: Step 1: Create a Search Widget
docs.text:
Search widgets allow users to filter data based on attribute fields from vector layers. Each widget is saved using the layer’s internal identifiers.

  1. From the Project List page, click the Layers icon.

  2. In the row for the landuse layer, click the Widgets List icon.

  3. Click Add New Widget to create a new one.

  4. In the Widget Creation Form, fill out the fields:

    Field Field Input Description Type Search Widget type Name Land Use Search Label that appears to end users Search Title Land Use Search Internal name of the widget Field type Field used for querying Widget SelectBox UI element used for the search input Alias Land Use Type Display name shown in the interface Operator = (equal) Query operator applied to the field

  5. Click OK to save.

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

docs.title: Step 2: Create a Plots Widget
docs.text:
The QPlotly widget lets users view interactive charts created in QGIS using the DataPlotly plugin. These plots are saved as .xml files and integrated into your WebGIS project.

  1. From the Project List page, click the Layers icon.

  2. In the row for the natural layer, click the QPlotly Widget icon.

  3. Click New QPlotly Widget to upload a new chart.

  4. Upload the file: qplotly_natural-type-distribution.xml.

  5. Click OK to save.

Image credit: G3W-SUITE

Next up: We’ll walk you through enabling editing tools so users can update data directly within your WebGIS service.

docs.title: What is GeoNode?
docs.text:
GeoNode is an open-source geospatial content management system (CMS) for managing, sharing, and publishing geospatial data and interactive maps via a web interface.

It integrates data creation, metadata editing, and map visualization in one platform, making it accessible to both technical and non-technical users. GeoNode allows datasets to be shared publicly or restricted to specific users.

It also includes social features like user profiles, commenting, and rating to support collaboration and data quality control. GeoNode is flexible and developer-friendly, making it easy to extend, customize, or integrate into other applications.

Image credit: GeoNode

docs.title: Key Capabilities
docs.text:
• Upload and manage datasets

    Seamlessly handle vector and raster data for efficient storage and access

  • Create interactive web maps

    Build dynamic, user-friendly maps for visualizing spatial information

  • Publish rich metadata

    Maintain high data quality and traceability with detailed metadata records

  • Control access securely

    Set precise user and group permissions for role-based content management

  • Encourage community engagement

    Use social features like profiles, comments, and ratings to foster collaboration

  • Extend and integrate easily

    Leverage GeoNode’s modular architecture and APIs to fit into your existing systems

docs.title: Troubleshooting Common Issues
docs.text: Why does my layer break when I upload it?      Layer names with special or non-standard characters (e.g., em dashes, smart quotes) can cause errors.        Fix: Use only standard ASCII characters like regular hyphens (-), letters, and numbers.    Why are duplicate layers created when pushing from QGIS?      Pushing edits from the original QGIS layer again after pushing creates duplicates.        Fix: Close the original QGIS layer after pushing, then fetch the layer from GeoNode and edit that to avoid duplicates.    My uploaded layer doesn’t show up in GeoNode — what’s wrong?      It might be an import error or file format issue. Check if your file is zipped properly and in a supported format like Shapefile or GeoPackage. Also, verify upload logs for errors.    I get an error about geometry types when uploading a layer, how to fix it?      GeoNode expects consistent geometry types. For example, a "LineString" layer should not contain "MultiLineString" features.        Fix: Use QGIS’s "Multipart to Singleparts" tool or similar to ensure geometries are consistent before upload.    Why can’t I see certain layers or maps on the public site?      The layer or map might be private or restricted. Check the “Sharing” permissions and ensure the "Anonymous Users" group has view rights if you want public access.    I uploaded a zipped shapefile, but it’s missing attributes — why?      Make sure all required components of the shapefile (.shp, .shx, .dbf, .prj) are included in the ZIP file. If even one is missing, GeoNode may not import it correctly.    My layer appears blank in the map viewer — what’s wrong?      Your layer might be outside the current map extent or missing a coordinate reference system (CRS).        Fix: Check your layer in QGIS, reproject it to EPSG:4326 if needed, and re-upload.    Upload fails with a "timeout" or "server error"      Large files can cause timeouts or memory issues. Try simplifying geometries or reducing file size. If the problem persists, contact your GeoNode administrator for upload limits or server logs.    Styling changes in the map viewer aren’t saving      After applying style changes, make sure you click the **Save** button in the map composer. Also confirm you have edit permissions for the map or layer.    I can’t upload a layer due to a “duplicate name” error      GeoNode does not allow two layers with the same name. Rename your layer in QGIS or during the upload process to ensure it’s unique.

docs.title: Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)
docs.text: Can I upgrade my product or plan?      Not yet. At the moment, upgrading from one product tier to another is not supported. However, this feature is actively being worked on and will be available in a future release. Stay tuned!    Can I use a custom domain name for my GeoNode instance?      Currently, custom domains are not supported. This is a frequently requested feature and is already on the roadmap. We’re working to make this available in an upcoming version.    How do I update an existing layer on GeoNode via QGIS?      Fetch the existing layer from GeoNode using the plugin, make your edits on this fetched layer, then push your changes back to GeoNode to update without creating duplicates.    What file formats can I upload to GeoNode?      GeoNode supports zipped Shapefiles, GeoPackages, and CSVs with geometry columns. Ensure your data matches one of these for successful uploads.    How do I set permissions for my layers and maps?      After uploading, use the “Sharing” tab to assign view and edit permissions to users or groups. This controls who can access or modify your content.    Can I create maps combining multiple layers?      Yes! You can create composite maps by adding multiple layers in the GeoNode map viewer. Save your map to share or publish it.    How can I delete a layer or map from GeoNode?      Navigate to the layer or map’s detail page, click on the “Delete” button (if you have permissions), and confirm the deletion. Note this action is permanent.    How do I change the coordinate system of a layer?      Use QGIS to reproject the layer to a standard CRS like EPSG:4326 before uploading. GeoNode relies on consistent spatial references for accurate display and analysis.    Can I collaborate with teammates on a shared map?      Yes. Set map and layer permissions to allow viewing or editing by specific users or groups. Use the "Sharing" tab on each resource’s page to configure access.    Can I attach documents or metadata to a layer?      Yes, you can add rich metadata including descriptions, keywords, licensing, and even external documents using the Metadata tab on the layer page.

docs.title: Why Choose this Product?
docs.text:
GeoNode is a ready-to-use Spatial Data Infrastructure (SDI) platform designed to help organizations effortlessly share, visualize, and collaborate on geospatial data—eliminating the need to build complex systems from scratch. Here’s what makes GeoNode stand out:

  • Effortless Data Publishing

    Upload vector and raster datasets such as Shapefiles, GeoJSON, or GeoTIFF directly through your web browser. GeoNode instantly publishes them as standard OGC services (WMS, WFS, WCS), making your data accessible across platforms.

  • Comprehensive Metadata Management

    Each dataset is automatically documented with ISO-compliant metadata—title, abstract, tags, bounding box, and more—ensuring your content is easily discoverable, interoperable, and well-organized.

  • Dynamic Interactive Map Builder

    Create customized maps by combining uploaded layers. Style maps on the fly, configure symbology, and generate embeddable map viewers—all within the browser, no client software needed.

  • Granular Access Control & Security

    Set precise permissions at the user or group level to control who can view, edit, download, or publish datasets and maps, helping you maintain data integrity and compliance.

  • Powerful Search & Discovery Tools

    Utilize full-text and faceted search to quickly find datasets, maps, documents, and users. Search results include live map previews for easy visual context.

  • Flexible, Extensible Architecture

    Built on robust open-source components like Django, GeoServer, PostGIS, Celery, and optionally Elasticsearch, GeoNode’s modular design allows you to extend functionality and integrate additional services as your needs evolve.

docs.title: What Size Should I Buy?
docs.text:
GeoNode is fully open-source with no licensing fees, giving you the flexibility to tailor your deployment to fit your organization’s scale and performance needs. Here’s a quick guide to help you decide:

  1. Small / Development Deployment

    Aspect Details Architecture All-in-One: Django, GeoServer, PostGIS, and Celery run together on a single (VM) or container Use Cases Proof-of-concept projects, small teams or individual users, and local testing environments Benefits Simple setup, minimal resource requirements, quick deployment.

  2. Medium / Production Deployment

    Aspect Details Architecture Two-Tier: Separate database and GeoServer from web application. Includes a dedicated Celery worker and optional Elasticsearch for faceted search. Use Cases Departmental portals and moderate user traffic and data volume. Benefits Improved performance, scalability, and search functionality.

  3. Large / Enterprise Deployment

    Aspect Details Architecture High-Availability Cluster: Multiple web servers behind a load balancer, clustered GeoServer instances, redundant databases, and Celery autoscaling. Supports integration with CDN, authentication federation (LDAP/SAML), and monitoring tools. Use Cases National-scale Spatial Data Infrastructures (SDIs) and mission-critical applications demanding high reliability and uptime. Benefits Maximum scalability, fault tolerance, security, and operational monitoring.

Choose the deployment size that best aligns with your organization’s number of users and teams, data volume and complexity, as well as the required performance and reliability levels. All options leverage the free, community-driven GeoNode ecosystem, offering flexibility without any licensing costs.

After checkout, your service will begin deploying automatically. You’ll receive a notification when it's ready for use.

Sort Option Details Date Most recent or Least recent Alphabetical A → Z or Z → A Popularity Most popular

Clicking on any of the following tabs will take you to its dedicated page and display all available items of that type:

Each resource tile includes:

Element Description Thumbnail Visual preview of the resource, such as a map snapshot or file icon. Title Custom name given to the resource. docs.title: Glossary of Terms
docs.text:
Not sure what a layer, dashboard, or GeoStory is? This quick glossary breaks down key GeoNode terms to help you get oriented.

Term Description 📦 Bounding Box The smallest rectangle (min X, min Y, max X, max Y) that fully contains the spatial extent of a dataset. 📊 Dashboard A MapStore workspace combining widgets—charts, tables, counters, text, and maps—for interactive data analysis. 🗂️ Dataset A spatial layer (vector or raster) uploaded to GeoNode. Datasets are served via OGC services (WMS, WFS, WCS) and described with metadata. 📎 Document Any non-spatial file (e.g., PDF, image, spreadsheet, SLD) uploaded to GeoNode. Can be associated with datasets or projects. 📖 GeoStory A storytelling tool using MapStore. Combines text, images, and interactive maps into scrollable narratives. 👥 Group A collection of users with shared permissions. Groups can be granted rights to view, edit, or manage GeoNode resources. 🗺️ Layer The renderable representation of a dataset in GeoServer. Often used interchangeably with "dataset" in GeoNode. 🧭 Map A saved composition of one or more layers shown in the Map Viewer. Includes metadata, sharing settings, and embed options. 🖥️ Map Viewer The interactive interface for building maps: add datasets, configure styles, and save compositions. 🌐 OGC Services Standards for web-based geospatial services: WMS (maps), WFS (features), WCS (rasters), and CSW (metadata). 🛡️ Permission Levels Define allowed actions on a resource: View, Download, Edit, and Manage. 📚 Resource A generic term for any item managed in GeoNode: datasets, maps, documents, dashboards, geostories, etc. 🎨 SLD (Styled Layer Descriptor) XML format for defining how layers appear. Used by GeoServer and editable from within GeoNode. 🖌️ Style SLD or CSS rules defining visual properties of layers—colors, symbols, stroke width, fill, opacity, and more.

docs.title: Integrating With Other Tools
docs.text: GeoNode makes it easy to work across platforms by exposing all datasets through standard OGC services, including WMS, WFS, and WCS. This means you can load layers directly into desktop GIS tools like QGIS or embed them in web applications with minimal setup.

docs.title: Connecting GeoNode to QGIS via WMS
docs.text:
You can easily load GeoNode layers into QGIS using the WMS (Web Map Service) protocol. This allows you to view and interact with published map layers directly from your GeoNode instance. To get started, open QGIS and navigate to: Layer → Add Layer → Add WMS/WMTS Layer…

Click New and enter the connection details below:

Field Value Name GeoNode WMS URL http://.sta.do.kartoza.com/geoserver/ows?service=WMS&version=1.3.0&request=GetCapabilities

Click OK, then Connect to fetch the list of available layers. Select the layer you want to view (e.g., geonode:landuse), then click Add. The layer will load into your QGIS map canvas and be ready for styling, analysis, or overlaying with other datasets.

Image credit: QGIS 💡 Ensure that the layer is shared publicly in GeoNode or that you are authenticated to access restricted content.

docs.title: Embedding a GeoNode Layer in Leaflet
docs.text: You can display GeoNode layers on a custom web map using Leaflet and WMS. Follow these steps to embed a published layer in your HTML page:

docs.title: Step 1: Include Leaflet’s CSS and JS
docs.text:
In your HTML <head>, add the following:

<link rel="stylesheet" href="https://unpkg.com/leaflet/dist/leaflet.css"/>
<script src="https://unpkg.com/leaflet/dist/leaflet.js"></script>

docs.title: Step 2: Add a Map Container
docs.text:
In your <body>, create a container for the map:

<div id="map" style="height: 400px;"></div>

docs.title: Step 3: Initialise the Map and Add the WMS Layer
docs.text:
Still within the <body>, insert a script that sets up your map and loads the GeoNode WMS layer:

<script>
const map = L.map('map').setView([52.51, 13.40], 12); // Berlin centre
L.tileLayer.wms('http://<geonode_application_name>.sta.do.kartoza.com/geoserver/ows', {
   layers: 'geonode:landuse',
   format: 'image/png',
   transparent: true,
   attribution: '© GeoNode'
}).addTo(map);
</script>

docs.title: Step 4: View the Map
docs.text:
Save the file and open it in your browser. The GeoNode layer will be displayed in the Leaflet map.

Image credit: QGIS 📝 Be sure to update the application hostname and layer name to match your GeoNode instance.

docs.title: Accessing GeoNode WFS
docs.text:
To retrieve raw vector feature data such as GeoJSON or GML, use the Web Feature Service (WFS) endpoint exposed by GeoServer.

Example WFS URL (GeoJSON Output):

http://<geonode_application_name>.sta.do.kartoza.com/geoserver/ows?service=WFS&version=2.0.0&request=GetFeature&typeName=tutorial:buildings&outputFormat=application/json

docs.title: How to Use
docs.text:
You can paste this URL into:

  • Postman or any API testing tool to inspect feature responses
  • curl in your terminal to retrieve data directly
  • Web mapping libraries such as Leaflet or OpenLayers that support WFS

Example with curl:

curl "http://<geonode_application_name>.sta.do.kartoza.com/geoserver/ows?service=WFS&version=2.0.0&request=GetFeature&typeName=tutorial:buildings&outputFormat=application/json"

📝 Replace both the application name and layer name with your actual GeoNode instance and dataset.

docs.title: Managing Users & Permissions
docs.text:
GeoNode offers a flexible, role-based permission system that gives you fine-grained control over how each resource is shared and accessed. Resources can be shared with:

  • Anyone (public access)
  • Registered members (all logged-in users)
  • Specific users or groups

Each resource can be assigned one of the following permission levels:

Level Description None Only the resource owner can access or modify it. View Allows others to view metadata and preview the resource. Download Grants view access along with the ability to download files or layers. Edit Enables changes to metadata, styles, attributes (for datasets), or map settings. Manage Full administrative access, including updating, deleting, changing share settings, and publishing.

docs.title: Opening the Share Panel
docs.text:
To manage who can access your resource, start by clicking View on the resource tile. Then, from the top navigation bar within the viewer, select Resource → Share to access the sharing options.

Image credit: GeoNode

docs.title: Setting Permissions
docs.text:
Within the Share with people and groups panel, you can define access levels for:

  • Anyone (public access)
  • Registered members (all logged-in users)

To assign roles to specific individuals or groups, click the Add Users / Groups button and choose the appropriate permission level.

Example Setting Result Public: View Members: View Anyone can see the resource. Downloads require a direct link or higher-level access. Public: None Members: View The resource is hidden from the public but visible to all logged-in users. Group: Manage Only users in the specified group can edit, delete, or update sharing settings.

Image credit: GeoNode

docs.title: Saving Changes
docs.text:
Once you've set the appropriate permissions, click Resources → Save to apply and confirm your updates.

Image credit: GeoNode

docs.title: Quickstart: 5-Minute Tutorial
docs.text: Follow these quick steps to upload your first dataset and publish a map in GeoNode.

docs.title: Data & Preparation
docs.text: GeoNode makes it easy to upload, store, and prepare spatial data for sharing. This page introduces the formats, storage methods, and metadata options used in the manual.

docs.title: Geospatial Data Handling
docs.text:
GeoNode supports uploading vector and raster datasets through a simple web form. Vector formats include Shapefiles, GeoJSON, CSV, KML, and KMZ. Raster data like satellite imagery is stored as GeoTIFF files.

Feature Vector Data Raster Data Formats Shapefile, GeoJSON, CSV, KML, KMZ GeoTIFF Storage Converted into geospatial DB tables Stored as GeoTIFF files Examples Roads, boundaries, facilities Satellite imagery, aerial photos Projection Handling Preserved and reprojected for map display Preserved in original projection Map Usage Searchable, combinable with other layers Searchable, used as basemaps

GeoNode supports standardized metadata, particularly ISO 19139 and ISO 19115. You can:

  • Edit metadata manually after upload
  • Auto-fill metadata by uploading XML files (ISO, FGDC, Dublin Core)
  • Expose data via OGC APIs like CSW, WFS, and WMS

GeoNode also offers a built-in style editor to adjust layer appearance directly from the browser.

docs.title: Data Preperation
docs.text:
This manual uses a prepackaged dataset of central Berlin, extracted from the BBBike OSM Extract Service. You can download the ready-to-use package here:

  • Manual_Data_GeoNode.zip

After unzipping, you’ll find the following folders:

  • 📁 Data – Shapefiles of Berlin’s city center, extracted from BBBike OSM.
  • 📁 Style – Predefined .sld files for symbolizing each layer.
  • 📁 Doc – Includes a README with information on the dataset and extract process.

💡 Want to use your own area? Head to the BBBike Extract Service to generate a custom dataset.

Next up: Now that your data is prepared, we’ll walk you through how to upload your datasets to GeoNode and get them ready for use on your map.

docs.title: Uploading Datasets
docs.text: In GeoNode, datasets represent either vector or raster spatial data and form the foundation of your spatial content. Each dataset includes rich metadata and supports collaboration through comments and ratings. Uploading datasets is essential for sharing and managing spatial information on your GeoNode instance.

docs.title: Step 1: Access the Upload Page
docs.text:
1. From the GeoNode Homepage, click the Dataset tab.

  2. Then, select the New button and choose Upload dataset from the dropdown.

Image credit: GeoNode

💡 You can also start the upload process from the All Resources page via Add Resource → Upload dataset.

docs.title: Step 2: Select and Upload Files
docs.text:
1. On the Upload a Dataset page, click Select files....

  2. Navigate to the Data folder and select all 5 components of the landuse shapefile.

  3. Once selected, click Upload.

GeoNode will display a progress bar while it uploads and unpacks the shapefile.

Image credit: GeoNode

docs.title: Step 3: View Your Dataset
docs.text:
Once the upload is complete, click View to open your new dataset.

This takes you to the Dataset Detail page, where you can:

  • Interact with the dataset on a map viewer
  • Edit metadata such as title, tags, and abstract
  • Download the original files
  • Leave comments or rate the dataset

Image credit: GeoNode

Next up: We’ll show you how to style your uploaded dataset for better visual presentation.

docs.title: Uploading Documents
docs.text:
GeoNode allows you to upload and share a wide variety of documents that support geospatial data — such as reports, spreadsheets, presentations, images, and more. These can help give context or supplementary detail to datasets, maps, and layers.

Document Type Supported File Types Reports .doc, .docx, .txt, .odt Conceptual Notes .doc, .docx, .txt, .odt Posters .pdf, .jpg, .png, .tif, .tiff Spreadsheets .xls, .xlsx, .ods Presentations .ppt, .pptx, .odp Images .gif, .jpg, .png, .tif, .tiff PDFs .pdf Zip Files .rar, .zip, .gz Styled Layer Descriptor (SLD) .sld Metadata Files .xml, .qml External URLs Web resource links (no file extension)

docs.title: Step 1: Open the Upload Page
docs.text:
1. From the Homepage, click the Documents tab.

  2. Then click the New button to start uploading a new document.

Image credit: GeoNode

💡 You can also upload documents from the All Resources page via Add Resource → Upload document.

docs.title: Step 2: Select & Upload the File
docs.text:
1. On the Document Upload page, click Select files....

  2. Navigate to your document (e.g. the README in the Doc folder).

  3. Click Upload.

Image credit: GeoNode

docs.title: Step 3: View & Manage the Document
docs.text:
Once uploaded, click View to open the Document Detail page. Here, you can:

  • Edit metadata
  • Share the link
  • Download the file
  • Delete or replace it

Image credit: GeoNode

Next up: Learn how to publish a map by combining layers, styles, and basemaps into a shareable interactive view.

docs.title: Creating a Map
docs.text: In GeoNode, maps are interactive views made by combining multiple datasets (layers). You can use the built-in Map Composer to create, style, and save these maps as GeoNode resources. Once published, maps can be enriched with metadata, ratings, and user comments.

docs.title: Step 1: Create a New Map
docs.text:
1. On the Homepage, go to the Maps tab.

  2. Click the New button to open the map composer.

Image credit: GeoNode

💡 You can also create maps from the All Resources page via Add Resource → Create map.

docs.title: Step 2: Add a Dataset

1. In the Map Viewer, click Add Dataset from the top navigation bar.

  2. In the Dataset Catalog, select the landuse layer you uploaded earlier.

Image credit: GeoNode

docs.title: Step 3: Save Your Map
docs.text:
1. Click the Resources menu in the top toolbar and choose Save As.

  2. In the popup, enter a Title and Description for your new map.

  3. Click Save.

Image credit: GeoNode

Next up: Explore GeoNode’s other powerful tools — GeoStories and Dashboards — to bring your data to life.

docs.title: Other Useful Tools
docs.text: GeoNode offers two powerful tools to help you communicate your data more effectively: Dashboards for dynamic data analysis and GeoStories for immersive storytelling.

docs.title: Dashboard
docs.text:
Dashboards are interactive workspaces where you can combine maps, charts, tables, text, and counters. These widgets can be connected to allow deeper exploration and analysis of your data. Dashboards are useful when you need to:

  • Provide a visual summary of complex datasets
  • Create interactive views with linked widgets
  • Conduct basic analytics across multiple layers

To create a new dashboard:

  1. From the Homepage, go to Add Resource → Create Dashboard.

  2. An empty dashboard will open.

  3. Click Add Widget and choose the type (e.g. map, chart, counter, table, text).

  4. Customize each widget and connect them as needed.

Image credit: GeoNode

docs.title: GeoStories
docs.text:
GeoStories let you combine text, interactive maps, images, and videos into rich, scrollable narratives — perfect for telling stories with data. With GeoStories, you can:

  • Craft multimedia narratives
  • Embed GeoNode maps and documents
  • Add external media (images, videos, iframes)

To create a GeoStory:

  1. From the Homepage, go to Add Resource → Create GeoStory.

  2. Add sections using the Add Section button at the bottom of the container.

  3. Use the Edit Mode button to insert maps, images, and videos from GeoNode or external sources.

Image credit: GeoNode

docs.title: Styling Data
docs.text: Maps help you understand data better by visualizing it in different ways. In GeoNode, each dataset gets a Default Style based on its content. When uploading a dataset, a default style is created automatically — which you can adjust to best tell your data’s story.

docs.title: Step 1: Open the Styles Panel
docs.text:
1. On the Datasets page, click View to open your dataset.

  2. In the top navigation bar, click Edit → Edit Style.

  3. The Styles Panel will open, showing the default style and editing tools.

Image credit: GeoNode

docs.title: Step 2: Edit the Style
docs.text:
1. In the Visual Editor, you can adjust style attributes and define styling rules.

  2. Use the 3-dot menu next to the default rule to select Classification style.

  3. Choose your preferred:

    • Color ramp
    • Classification attribute
    • Interval method & size
    • Outline color & width

  4. To save your style changes, click Apply.

Image credit: GeoNode

docs.title: Step 3: Preview the Dataset
docs.text:
Click Go back to ... to view your updated dataset.

Image credit: GeoNode

💡 You can also upload a custom style via Edit → Upload Style using an SLD file.

docs.title: What is GeoServer?
docs.text:
GeoServer is a powerful, Java-based server application that enables users to publish, edit, and share geospatial data. Built on open standards set by the Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC), it promotes interoperability and flexibility in map creation and spatial data management.

Image credit: GeoServer

docs.title: Publish and Share Spatial Data
docs.text:
GeoServer enables you to publish spatial data on the web using open standards like the Web Map Service (WMS). It can generate maps in a variety of output formats and works seamlessly with OpenLayers, a widely-used open-source web mapping library.

In addition to WMS, GeoServer supports several other OGC services:

Service Abbreviation Purpose Web Map Service WMS Serves dynamic map images rendered from spatial data. Web Feature Service WFS Provides access to and editing of vector (feature) data. Web Coverage Service WCS Shares raster data (coverages) such as satellite imagery or elevation grids. Web Map Tile Service WMTS Delivers pre-rendered map tiles for fast performance in web and mobile applications. Web Processing Service WPS Enables server-side geospatial processing and analysis of data.

GeoServer’s modular architecture allows you to expand its capabilities through extensions. The WPS extension, for example, unlocks powerful on-the-fly geoprocessing. You can also create your own custom plugins to suit specific workflows.

By publishing data through GeoServer, you empower others to access and embed your spatial content in websites, applications, and platforms — promoting open access, collaboration, and transparency.

docs.title: Built on Free and Open Source Software
docs.text:
GeoServer is fully open source and free to use, significantly lowering the cost of entry compared to proprietary GIS platforms. Its open development model invites contributions from the global community, ensuring ongoing improvements, quick bug fixes, and steady evolution.

With no vendor lock-in and full access to the source code, GeoServer empowers users with flexibility, long-term sustainability, and independence from restrictive licensing.

docs.title: Seamless Integration With Mapping APIs
docs.text:
GeoServer works beautifully with leading open-source mapping libraries like OpenLayers and Leaflet, allowing you to build rich, interactive web maps using open tools.

It can also serve spatial data to a wide range of platforms and tools, including:

  • Google Maps
  • Google Earth
  • Microsoft Bing Maps
  • MapBox
  • ESRI ArcGIS

This makes GeoServer a highly interoperable solution for modern GIS and web mapping workflows.

Image credit: OpenLayers , Leaflet

docs.title: Join the Global GeoServer Community
docs.text:
GeoServer is supported by a passionate global community of developers, users, and service providers. Whether you're just getting started or you're an experienced GIS professional, there are many ways to engage, get help, and contribute:

📬 GeoServer User Forum Ask questions, share experiences, and learn from other GeoServer users around the world. 🛠️ Issue Tracker Report bugs, suggest features, or follow progress on upcoming improvements. 📦 GitHub Repository Contribute to the codebase, submit pull requests, or explore the inner workings of GeoServer. 🗓️ Release Roadmap Stay up to date with new versions, planned features, and release timelines. 📚 Official Documentation Access comprehensive guides, tutorials, and reference material for installing, configuring, and using GeoServer.

docs.title: Troubleshooting Common Issues
docs.text: Why won’t my data upload to GeoServer?      This can happen if the file format isn’t supported or the file is too large.        Fix: Use supported formats like Shapefile, GeoPackage, or GeoTIFF. For Shapefiles, ensure all related files (.shp, .shx, .dbf, .prj) are zipped together.    My layer appears but it’s blank — why?      Your data’s projection (CRS) may not match your map settings.        Fix: Check the layer’s CRS in QGIS or another GIS tool, and set the correct SRS in GeoServer when publishing.    I get an error when trying to save a style (SLD).      Errors often come from invalid XML or unsupported style parameters.        Fix: Validate your SLD using an XML validator or copy a working example and modify it carefully.    Why is my raster layer loading slowly?      Large raster files can take time to render.        Fix: Use overviews or pyramids, and ensure the file is in an efficient format like GeoTIFF with internal tiling.    I published my layer but can’t preview it.      The preview may fail if no style is assigned or if the layer is in a different workspace.        Fix: Assign a default style and check the workspace and store settings.    Why do I see a “Store not found” error?      This happens if the data store was deleted or its connection settings changed.        Fix: Recreate the store and republish the layer with the correct settings.    The colors in my map look wrong.      This can be caused by incorrect SLD values or mismatched color encoding.        Fix: Double-check your SLD code and ensure the correct hex color codes are used.    Why do some features not appear on the map?      Features outside the map extent or with geometry errors may not render.        Fix: Repair geometries in QGIS and verify the bounding box settings in GeoServer.    I can’t delete a layer from GeoServer.      Layers must be removed from both the Layer list and their Data Store.        Fix: First delete the layer, then remove its store and associated files.    GeoServer says “Out of Memory” when rendering.      Large datasets can exceed the Java heap memory allocation.        Fix: Increase the Java heap size in the GeoServer startup settings or optimize your dataset.

docs.title: Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)
docs.text: Can I upload multiple layers at once?      Yes. You can zip multiple Shapefiles or upload multi-layer GeoPackages, and publish them individually in GeoServer.    What file formats does GeoServer support?      Common formats include Shapefile, GeoPackage, PostGIS, GeoTIFF, and CSV. Additional formats may be available through plugins.    Can I edit a layer directly in GeoServer?      No. GeoServer serves data but does not allow direct editing. Edit your data in QGIS or another GIS tool, then re-upload or update the store.    How do I change the default style of a layer?      Go to the layer’s Publishing tab, select your preferred style, and set it as default.    Can I password-protect certain layers?      Yes. Use GeoServer’s security settings to assign roles and restrict layer access.    Does GeoServer support WMS, WFS, and WCS?      Yes. GeoServer supports OGC standards including WMS (maps), WFS (features), and WCS (coverages).    How can I speed up layer loading?      Use caching with GeoWebCache, simplify geometries, and optimize file formats.    Can I host my data in the cloud?      Yes. You can connect GeoServer to cloud storage or cloud-hosted databases like AWS S3, Google Cloud Storage, or remote PostGIS.    Can I host raster data in GeoServer?      Yes, GeoServer supports raster formats such as GeoTIFF, JPEG2000, and others.    What’s the maximum file size I can upload?      This depends on your hosting plan and server configuration.        Tip: If you encounter upload limits, compress your dataset (e.g., using a zipped Shapefile or GeoPackage) or contact your administrator to increase the limit.

docs.title: Why Choose this Product?
docs.text:
GeoServer is a powerful and widely adopted open-source server platform for sharing geospatial data. It enables you to publish vector and raster data using open standards, making it easy to integrate with existing systems and web mapping frameworks.

Whether you're building a lightweight internal service or a robust, public-facing map platform, GeoServer gives you full control over how your spatial data is served and styled. Here’s why GeoServer stands out:

  • OGC-Compliant Data Publishing

    GeoServer supports key Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) standards such as WMS, WFS, WCS, WMTS, and WPS — allowing you to share, edit, and process spatial data across interoperable platforms with ease.

  • Flexible Styling With SLD and CSS

    Control the appearance of your maps down to the finest detail using Styled Layer Descriptor (SLD) or CSS-like styling. GeoServer gives you full control over symbology, labels, scale-dependent rendering, and more.

  • Scalable Raster and Vector Delivery

    Serve everything from high-resolution satellite imagery and elevation models to shapefiles and PostGIS layers. GeoServer is optimized for handling both tiled and dynamic map requests, even in high-demand environments.

  • Built for Interoperability

    GeoServer integrates well with open-source tools like QGIS, OpenLayers, and Leaflet, as well as proprietary platforms like ArcGIS and Google Earth. You can also connect to backend databases such as PostGIS, Oracle Spatial, and SQL Server.

  • Extendable and Customizable

    Add new capabilities via GeoServer’s plugin architecture, whether you need Web Processing Service (WPS), security extensions, or custom formats. It’s a developer-friendly platform designed for long-term adaptability.

docs.title: What Size Should I Buy?
docs.text:
GeoServer is designed to scale with your needs. Whether you're managing a simple departmental map service or running a national Spatial Data Infrastructure (SDI), our hosted GeoServer environments can be tailored to fit.

  1. Small / Basic Deployment

    Aspect Details Architecture Single-host setup with GeoServer and internal PostGIS (optional). Ideal for small teams or test environments. Use Cases Prototypes, academic use, single-user map publication, or non-critical internal tools. Benefits Fast to deploy, minimal overhead, and budget-friendly.

  2. Medium / Production Deployment

    Aspect Details Architecture Two-tier setup with dedicated PostGIS database, separate GeoServer instance, and optional external data stores or extensions. Use Cases Government departments, NGOs, consultancies, or organizations publishing several datasets and maps publicly. Benefits Improved stability, isolated services, support for security extensions, better performance under moderate load.

  3. Large / Enterprise Deployment

    Aspect Details Architecture High-availability setup with load-balanced GeoServer instances, clustered databases, tile caching, and optional CDN and security integrations (OAuth2, LDAP, SAML). Use Cases Enterprise SDIs, national portals, and high-traffic applications that require robust performance, redundancy, and uptime guarantees. Benefits Scalability, fault tolerance, secure access control, disaster recovery support, and full integration with external systems.

No matter the size or scope of your deployment, GeoServer provides a rock-solid foundation for open geospatial data services. With Kartoza’s hosted offering, you also get expert configuration, monitoring, and support — so you can focus on using your data, not managing infrastructure.
